Description: Gold ear-ring: slightly inflated hollow ring with a loop at one end into which the other end is twisted; below is a cluster of four globules.
Curator's comments: This form of a hollow ring with added granules is common in the 2nd or 3rd century AD, with a parallel found in Amman with coins of Gallienus (253–266) and Aurelian (270–275) (Davidson and Oliver 1984, 126 nos 148, 149). Close parallels from Thonis-Herakleion were dated to the 6th–8th century AD (Goddio and Fabre 2008, 298 no. 44); however, this group comprises collected damaged jewellery of various dates gathered for recycling. Earrings of this type are depicted on contemporary Roman mummy portraits (Borg 1996, 171, pls. 78:1, 79:1), but derived from much earlier precedents (Pisano 1987, 80). Borg, B. 1996, Mumienporträts: Chronologie und kultureller Kontext, Mainz. Davidson, P.J. and Oliver Jr, A. 1984, Ancient Greek and Roman Gold Jewellery in the Brooklyn Museum, New York. Goddio, F. and Fabre, D. (eds), 2008, Egypt’s Sunken Treasures, Munich. Pisano, G. 1987, ‘Jewellery’, in R. D. Barnett and C. Mendleson (eds.) Tharros: a Catalogue of Material in the British Museum from Phoenician and Other Tombs at Tharros, Sardinia, London, 78-95.
Bibliographic references: Jewellery / Catalogue of the Jewellery, Greek, Etruscan, and Roman, in the Departments of Antiquities, British Museum. (2501)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (QE.2)
